*HEALTH RISK: TOXIC(POISONOUS); may be fatal if inhaled or absorbed through
skin. Fire will produce irritating, corrosive and/or toxic gases. Contact with gas or liquefied gas may
cause burns, severe injury and/or frostbite. 

PRIMARY ACTIVITIES:Chlorine at the water treatment plant is used to treat raw water from Laurel River to make potable drinking water for the city of Corbin and the surrounding areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION: EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY: City Utilities Commission is committed to safety and the implementation of safety procedures. Chlorine tanks at the water treatment plant are housed in an separate building. The chlorine building is equipped with an alarm system to nofity employees of leaks, vents close if alarm s

ounds, containing chemical inside building. Employees are trained in the use of the class B repair kit (A KIT USE TO CONTROL LEAKS AROUND VALVES).

MANAGEMENT IN SAFETY: General Manger Ronald W. Herd is committed to safety and the implementation of safety procedures at City Utilities Commission. Each year City Utilities Commission holds an emergency management meeting at the Corbin City Hall with the Corbin city fire department, Corbin city police department, and Whitley County Emergency management Coordinator Steve Schwartz. The topic of discussion, action to be taken in the event of a chemical release at the Water treatment plant. The meetings are open to the public.

REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT WATER TREATMENT PLANT: The water treatment plant is located on Hinkle Street just off of Highway 312 (Gordon Hill). The Water treatment plant produces potable drinking water for the city of Corbin and the surrounding area. Chlorine is used to treat the water brought into the plant from the laurel river intake on Old City Dam Road. The water treatment plant houses eight (8) cylinders at a weight of 2000lbs. each. The water plant employs three (3) full time employees and one (1) part-time employee. Two (2) employees hold degreesin chemistry.  

                                                                                                                                                                      
                                                                                                                                                                              PROTECTIVE ACTION IN CASE OF A CHEMICAL RELEASE: Wost-case release scenario, in the event of a chemical release from a 2000lb chlorine tank at the water treatment plant , all local resident in a3.50 mile area would be ask to evacuate by local radio stations WKDP and WCTT along with police and fire department employees going door to door. A release of this size will require the expertise of a leve

l III agency.                                                                                                                                                                                                          
If a leak occurs between the Chlorine building and main building, the emergency shut-off valve will close, and the excess flow valve will divert the overflow.

SAFETY: Change chlorine tanks involves two employees, one employee in the tank room, the second in the control room. If the employee in the tank room is over come by chemicals, the employee in the control room has a SCBA (SELF-CONTAINED BREATHING APPARATUS) and phone, the employee can call for help and retrieve the down employee and use repair kit to contain leaking chemical.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTROY:  City Utilities Commission has not had a chemical accident in the past five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM: In the event of a spill or release, radio stations WKDP and WCTT along with police and fire sirens will be utilized to notift residents to evacuate. Also, police and fire personnel will go door to door to insure the evacuation of all affected resident. Schools and churches may be used as shelters if necessity arises.

Baptist Regional Medical Center has a decontamination unit specifically trained in chemical emergencies, and will accept patients contaminated with chlorine and have the capability to provide appropriate care, they are equipped with a heliport for the immediate transport of patients if needed.

The primary response point is at facility's front gate. If this is impractical, the alternate response point is the northeast corner of Kentucky State Route 312 (Gordon Hill Road) and Highland Avenue. At either response point the facility representative will have in hand a copy of the facility Title III, and appropriate MSDS and be prepared to brief response personnel. Support units will report and await assignment by local organizations.

Actions will be taken for the protection of

the emergency workers on-site and populated areas off site. These actions will depend upon the amount of chemical, weather conditions and other hazards involved, such as fire.

Entry into the evacuated area will be restricted until the highest-ranking official representing the City of Corbin, Kentucky, (i.e. Mayor, Mayor Pro-term or City Commissioners) determine it permissible for authorized personnel to enter.


                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                


RESPONSE LEVELS:

LEVEL I:              Emergency Condition Description:
                           An incident or threat of a release which can  be controlled by the first response agencies  and does not require evacuation of other than the  involved structure or outdoor area, The incident is confined to a small area and does not pose an immediate threat  to life or property. Contact local response agency's fire, police, medical, and any appropriate persons.

LEVEL II:                Limited Emergency Condition Description:
                             An incident involving a greater or larger area which poses a potential threat to life and property and which may require a limited evacuation of the surrounding area. Contact all  agencies in  Level I plus: HAZMAT TEAM, EOC STAFF, PUBLIC WORKS DEPT., RED CROSS, COUNTY  DES/EMA , STATE POLICE, AND PUBLIC  UTILITIES.

LEVEL III:                Full Emergency Condition Description:
                              An incident involving a severe hazard or a large area which poses an extreme threat to life and property and will probably require a large scale  evacuation, or an incident requiring the expertise or resources of county, state , federal or private agencies. Contact all Level I and  Level

II agencies plus the following: MUTUAL AID, STATE DES,  HREPS, HSC, USEPA, USCG, ATSDR, PEMA, AND OSC/RRT.

FACILITY EQUIPMENT:

Self-contained Breathing Apparatus (SCBA), Chemical Suits,Chlorine Alarm System, Chemical Respirator's, Gas monitors, Three Canister Breathing Apparatus.

COMMUNITY EQUIPMENT: City of Corbin Fire Department along with West Knox Fire Department are equipped with Self-Contained Breathing Units, and trained in First-Aid and CPR. (Both - Level I Agency)
                                                                                                                                                          


FACILITY TRAINING:

At present City Utilities Commision has seven (7) employees trained in the use of Respirator's, SCBAs, and the Class B repair kits. 


FACILITY EXERCISE PROGRAM:
Our facility at present has had on-site exercises but none on the county level.



SPILL CONTAINMENT:

In the event of a Chlorine release inside of the chlorine building the product could be contained within the  building thereby controlling the release of the product into the atmosphere. 

For personnel protection, keep upwind, wear appropriate class A or B type
protective clothing to include boots, protective gloves and goggles and use proper
breathing apparatus. Avoid breathing vapors or dusts. Wash away any material
which may have contacted the body with copious amounts of plain water or soap and
water.

CLEAN UP:

The  water treatment personnel will accomplish the clean up of any chemical residue, any residue will be put in plastic bags and placed in 55 gallon drums for storage and proper disposal.

 The Kentucky D.N.R. will approve disposal of waste.

MSDS- (Chlorine) the following steps should be taken in the event of a chlorine spill or leak. Move unprotected  personnel upwind. If a chlorine container is leaking
try to position it so that gas, rather than liquid leaks.  Using full protective
equipment, apply emergency- sealing device if possible. Cover

leak with
tarpaulin or plastic sheet to limit spread of chlorine.
